It's seems the LFP chemistry does a better charging to full. Most people don't charge EVs to full because it's not good for the battery. That's for NCA, but not LFP. LFP can be charged full without any concern of degradation. 

For a cheap EV, LFP batteries seem better and will deliver good charge performance. Right now, we're probably going to see 15-20 minutes to 80% charge. I wonder if the new 4580 batteries with LFP chemistry will do close to 20-25 minutes to full charge. IDK though. 

I personally think that once you get 80% in 20 minutes, it'll drive apartment dwellers to buy EVs. Once that happens, they'll start pressuring landlords to put in L2 chargers. And that'll start turning the tide against gas cars.

comment:
It's not about weight, it's really about side impact pole intrusion and roof crush.  The front edge of the rear door is effectively the B pillar in crew cab pickups and adds a huge amount of weight and engineering complexity.

In a pickup the cab isn't transferring a lot of roll stiffness, but in a unibody like a sedan, decoupling the rocker(which is nice and beefy on an EV) from the bodyside/roof reduces the stiffness by a large margin, putting more strain on every body panel in the system as a result.

comment:
Over the decades we've all gotten used to the comparatively glacial pace of ICE development. The next gen of your main commuter has the MPG and HP numbers shifted around a tiny bit, usually one sacrificed for the other and on a longer time scale both creep up together a bit. The new entertainment system is more compatible with your phone. A few more buttons.

So they make the fallacy in thinking EV development is similarly slow. It's not. A decade ago there were no large fast charging networks. Now there are several and they're doubling in size every two years. On top of that, just like you said, fast charging times are going down dramatically.

Saying this change will take *decades* is based on this old habit of thought because, traditionally, changes in the automotive industry take that long. That's no longer true.

comment:
Are you going to buy one?

Think about this from the manufacturer's POV:

* The cost of producing PHEVs is projected to remain flat for some time to come. ICE production costs are well-established and smaller batteries mean lower battery prices don't affect production costs as much.
* The cost of producing BEVs is projected to keep going down as battery prices go down
* Consumers have proven to be willing to pay *more* for a BEV than they normally would have
* Profit margins are there fore projected to be significantly higher for BEVs than any other vehicle

If you want a PHEV you'd better get one now. I see zero future for them. They're a 2010 solution for a world without fast charging networks and $1,000/kWh battery prices not 2021 where fast charging networks are doubling every year and battery prices are $100/kWh. Good luck getting one. Because of how the economics are working out you're only going to get less and less opportunity to buy a PHEV. $5k over MSRP without the options you want may be the best deal you'll see unless you wait to get one used.

comment:
PHEVs are going to go the way of physical keyboards on smartphones. Most people are in the habit of fueling up for road trips just like most people were in the habit of texting with physical keyboards. The idea of being 100% dependant on charging is a new thing and that fact alone makes people anxious just like the idea of touch screen typing was new.

The last keyboard Android I had I ended up regretting having the keyboard because swype ended up being so much better. Once I stopped using the keyboard it was just this extra, bulky, useless piece of equipment. Shortly after that I stopped seeing new phones with physical keyboards. More costly to produce and people discovered they didn't need or want them. Once again: the manufacturer is going to go the route of cutting production costs and you can't do that with PHEVs.

I'd never buy a PHEV because I'm now familiar with what it's like to have a 100% BEV and I've witnessed the fast charging network get built out around me at great speed. If I buy a new PHEV now with a 5 year loan I can see that before it's even paid off I'd lament having essentially a short-range EV with a gas engine in a world of full BEVs and fast charging. Oher people would have vehicles that are significantly more powerful than mine but just as capable for road trips and camping.

If Tesla is the iPhone of EVs who's going to be the Android of EVs and who's going to be the Nokia/BB/Windows Phone of EVs? Until there's a clear "Android" EV I can't see spending any good money unless it's a Tesla or repairs on our 2010 Outback. Otherwise I'd feel like a bag holder.
